item.title: Towards a global chaos

item.title: Dhaka’s geopolitical test
item.description: POLITICAL scientist Nicholas John Spykman observed that geography does not argue; it simply exists. The remark remains instructive. Geography imposes structural realities that states must navigate rather than debate. In a period marked by renewed great-power rivalry, these realities are again shaping strategic choices across the Indo-Pacific. As global politics......

item.title: An immediate priority
item.description: RAMADAN is here. Keeping prices affordable for ordinary people must be the government’s immediate priority. In Ramadan, family expenses naturally increase. People buy more rice, edible oil, sugar, lentils, dates, meat, eggs, fruit and other goods, but their income does not increase. According to the Bureau of Statistics, the overall inflation stood at 8.58 per cent in......

item.title: BNP’s economic test
item.description: JOBLESS growth defined much of Bangladesh’s recent past. Output expanded on paper, yet secure employment did not keep pace. That paradox unfolded under an increasingly authoritarian order that, by the end, relied more on coercion than consent. The fall of that regime came at a grave human cost. Hundreds lost their lives in the turmoil that preceded......

item.title: Corruption in road development projects must end

item.title: Illiberal currents and crossroads for progressive politics
